key_points: Qatar's top diplomat warns it's unclear when Kabul airport will reopen for flights.
Experts from Qatar and Turkey are working to reopen Kabul airport after the U.S. withdrawal.
The Taliban, now in control, have pledged to allow women and girls to go to school and people to travel freely.
In Herat, dozens of women protested for their rights, including participation in the Taliban's Cabinet.
The Taliban's previous rule in the late 1990s was marked by severe oppression, particularly towards women.
A recent suicide bombing during evacuation efforts killed 169 Afghans and 13 U.S. service members.
Kabul's airport closure has hindered escape for those fearing the Taliban and delayed humanitarian aid.
Qatar remains hopeful and engaged in dialogue with the Taliban to restart airport operations.
UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab emphasizes the need for engagement with the Taliban to verify their promises.
Afghan women protestors demand tangible action from the Taliban on their rights, vow to continue activism.
spokespersons: Mohammad bin Abdulrahman Al Thani (Qatari Foreign Minister)
